Post: "I thought I had finally kicked depression to the curb, but it turns out I'm just naturally prone to it. Despite all the positive changes I've made in my life, I still can't seem to shake it off."
Transferred_Post:
"I thought I had finally kicked depression to the curb, but it turns out I'm just naturally prone to it. Despite all the positive changes I've made in my life, I still can't seem to shake it off."

However, the causal attributions the person makes for the event determine the nature of depression that follows uncontrollable events. If the individual attributes the cause of the event to non-transient factors (stable attribution style), the depressive symptoms are expected to be long-lasting. In contrast, if the individual attributes the cause of the event to transient factors (unstable attribution style), the depressive symptoms are expected to be temporary.

Therefore, it is crucial to modify the attributional style to transform the attribution for uncontrollable adverse events from stable to unstable. To achieve this, you need to identify specific transient factors contributing to the event and incorporate them into your new post while maintaining the author's voice.

Post:
"I'm so tired of feeling like I'm stuck in this rut. No matter what I do, I just can't seem to shake off this depression. It's like it's a part of me, something that I'll never be able to escape. #depression #mentalhealth #stuck"

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the person's depression to their inherent nature or character, rather than to external factors. By saying "it's like it's a part of me," the person is implying that their depression is a chronic and long-lasting condition that they are unable to change or control.
